items.item_details:
By contracting with the State Chancellor's Office, the District may recover outstanding student debts owed such as enrollment fees and library fines.  Under the program, the State Chancellor's Office requests the Franchise Tax Board to offset (deduct) the amount owed to the District from the student's personal state income tax refund, lottery winnings, or other state refund.  The Franchise Tax Board remits any amounts offset to the State Chancellor's Office, which then authorizes the State Controller's Office to disburse the offset amount, less a 25% administrative fee, to the District.
	 
The program is one of a multi-pronged approach to recover outstanding student debts.  The District sends emails to students throughout the term advising of their outstanding balance and providing options to satisfy their outstanding balance (e.g., payment plan, financial aid, etc.).  Upon completion of the term, students who still have an outstanding balance despite receiving emails during the term are sent a letter advising that the balance remains outstanding, that a hold is on their account, the options available to them to satisfy their outstanding balance, and that failure to satisfy the outstanding debt may result in their account being referred to an external collection agency.
	 
Last year, the District referred $1,991,213 in outstanding student debt and recovered $233,872 through the 2013 program.

items.item_details:
The Campus Site Fencing Project is part of the Campus Site Improvements and Master Planning initiative approved by the Board in March 2013.  The Fencing project continues a Fencing plan started in 2012 to enhance campus aesthetics by providing consistent unified fencing around campus and controlling pedestrian and vehicular traffic for improved safety and security. 
	 
In March 2013, the District approved a Project Assignment Amendment with Joni L. Janecki & Associates Inc. (JJA), to provide design and construction phase administration services for the project.  Since March 2013, JJA has met regularly with the Design Committee made up of SJCC staff and administration to define the project scope.
	 
A public bidding process for fencing contractors was conducted between July 8, 2013 and July 29, 2013.  The project was advertised in local papers on July 8 and July 15, and published at 15 local builders’ exchanges and plan rooms.  In addition, invitations to bid were sent to over 25 contractors.  A mandatory pre-bid meeting was held on July 16, 2013 with approximately 8 interested fencing contractors.  Bids were opened at 3pm on July 29, 2013.  The lowest responsive and responsible bidder is Crusader Fence Co., Inc.  Crusader Fence did not submit its signed Appendix A and Appendix B of the Construction Careers Agreement (CCA) between the District and the Santa Clara and San Benito Counties Building Trades Council with its bid, however, Crusader Fence immediately remedied the situation and submitted the omitted documents prior to the end of bid opening day on July 29, 2013.  Staff has consulted with District’s legal counsel, Mr. Phillip Jaret, regarding the late document submittal.  It is Mr. Jaret’s opinion that “the failure of Crusader Fence to include the requisite signed PSA documents with its bid, but a later curing of that shortly thereafter by Crusader Fence with the executed documents, is a minor irregularity that can and should be waived by the District.  It did not provide Crusader Fence with any competitive advantage over the other bidders."
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees waive the minor irregularity in the Crusader Fence Co. response to Bid Document G2010.0057 and approve award of a contract to Crusader Fence Co., Inc. in the amount of $374,357 for the Site Fencing Project at San Jose City College.

items.item_details:
In April 2012 Evergreen Valley College (EVC) and the San Jose Evergreen Community College District (SJECCD) approached the Program Manager about upgrading various mechanical, electrical and plumbing (MEP) systems on the Evergreen Valley College Campus.  This work encompasses approximately 60 small upgrades and repairs into a consolidated project.  In February of 2013, a contract for design services was executed with the engineering firm GHD.  
	 
Initial bidding resulted in two bids at double the engineer’s estimate.  It was subsequently decided by the District to break out the work into separate smaller trade-specific packages to get the more critical work completed, resulting in the Evergreen Valley College Mechanical Upgrade Project.  
	 
In June 2013 the District invited bids from mechanical contractors for this work with an engineer’s estimate of $400,000.  During the bid period the project team contacted over 200 contractors including local businesses, minority owned businesses and women owned businesses.  In addition, the Santa Clara & San Benito County Building and Construction Trades Council notified various union-affiliated mechanical contractors in the area.  
	 
Five bids were received on July 18, 2013.  The apparent low bidder was EMCOR Services with a total bid amount of $330,301, however a technical review revealed that EMCOR Services had failed to include certain specific components of the project into their bid.  EMCOR Services was allowed to withdraw their bid and the second apparent low bidder was Heathorn & Associates Contractor, Inc. dba American Air Conditioning, Plumbing and Heating with a total bid amount of  $378,454.  The Board is asked to approve the award of a contract to Heathorn & Associates Contractor, Inc. dba American Air Conditioning, Plumbing and Heating.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve award of a contract to Heathorn & Associates Contractor, Inc. dba American Air Conditioning, Plumbing and Heating for the Evergreen Valley College Mechanical Upgrade Project in the amount of $378,454.

items.item_details:
On June 11, 2012 Evergreen Valley College suffered a serious six-day failure to the primary electrical system, which knocked power out to the entire campus and adjacent neighborhoods. During the investigation and effort to repair the failure, serious issues of age and lack of maintenance were identified throughout the system. An engineering firm was contracted to assess the system, and the resulting engineering report carried a recommendation that the entire primary system cabling be replaced and the numerous maintenance issues be addressed. 
	 
In August of 2012, the Board approved the Design Services Agreement for the Evergreen Valley College 21kV Electrical Upgrade Project (21kV Project) with Salas O’Brien. In September 2012, following completion of the design, the District invited bids from electrical contractors for the 21kV Project.  In October 2012, the Board approved the Construction Agreement for Radiant Electric, Inc. to upgrade the existing system.  In December 2012, major construction operations began and in January 2013, major construction operations were completed.  All construction work has been approved by the Engineer of Record, all closeout documents have been received, change orders have been approved and all contracts have been closed.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the Board of Trustees approve the notice of completion for the Evergreen Valley College 21kV Electrical Upgrade Project.

These revisions are the result of careful coordination and realignment with the current Facilities Master Plans and the planned implementation of the projects at each campus.
	 
Measure G-2010 Bond List Revision #5 includes the following actions:
	 
31109 Repurpose Boiler Plant - Savings from Water System Project to cover additional project costs.

The Board of Trustees voted to approve an award of RFP to Keifer Consulting at the June 11, 2013 board meeting in the amount of $277,800 for website redesign.  The District Office has completed the contract language and is ready to begin work on the project. (Contract and Terms and Conditions files attached) As reference, the following background information reviews the previous action.
	 
The District Office, San Jose City College, Evergreen Valley College, and Workforce Institute are all currently running on different web platforms that are not integrated and do not meet the needs of our constituents and does not align with the District Communications Plan.  The District issued an RFP to determine available options to put web resources on the same platform but allowing for the unique requirements of each of the four entities.  The following background details the process that was undertaken to recommend a vendor.
		 
Background:
On January 30, 2013, Bid Proposal 13-0221 for the Website Redesign Project for SJECCCD was announced.
Four proposals were received.
The Evaluation Committee was comprised of 3 Administrators from the District Office, 1 Administrator from Workforce Institute, 1 Administrator from Evergreen Valley College, and 1 Classified Member from the District Office.
The Evaluation Committee invited the four respondents to give a presentation on March 22, 2013.
Two respondents were asked to give another presentation on April 19, 2013, to end-users to determine their ability to interface with the end-users, to present their ideas for the website, to give a live demo, and to answer questions.
Based on these presentations and the overall performance the End-user/Evaluation Team/Information Systems Steering Group recommends Kiefer Consulting for website redesign and implementation in the amount not to exceed $277,800.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation the the Board of Trustees award a contract not to exceed $277,800 to Kiefer Consulting for website redesign and implementation.

items.item_details:
The Evergreen Valley College and San Jose City College have been working without a curriculum management system.  Much of the work of curriculum management is being done on paper, spreadsheets or other packages not intended for the purpose of curriculum management and the process is labor intensive.  The current practice does not meet the needs of the Colleges and they explored several solutions.  What was needed is a package that can automate much of the workflow involved in the process and interface with the state California Community College Chancellor's office.  Use of a curriculum management system, specifically designed to meet the needs of the Colleges and integrate into the state curriculum management system, provides a distinct advantage in managing and sharing curriculum materials with system community colleges and the California Community College Chancellor's office.
	 
In order to address the aforementioned situation and provide the Colleges with a proven method for meeting state and accreditation requirements, the District determined that an RFP process would be the most beneficial approach for securing a solution.  To complete the purchase and implement a solution to meet the needs of the Colleges in a timely fashion, purchasing put together the following schedule.
	 
6/21 – Bids goes out.
6/24 and 7/01 – Bids are advertised.
7/03 – Questions about bids must be received.
7/08 – Answers to bid questions must be sent back to vendors.
7/22 – Bids are due. 
7/23-7/25 – Bids are evaluated.
7/26 – Evaluation Committee Meets to come up with a short list for the Presentations and a list of what must be included in the Presentations.
7/29 – Short Listed Vendors are notified.
8/05 – Vendor Presentations and Recommendation.  All forms are to be completed by the end of the day and given to me before the Recommendation can be made.
8/06 - Recommendation for Award Letters are sent out.
8/06 – 8/12 – We work on the contract.
8/06 – 8/12 – Bid Protest window.
8/13 – Board Meets.
8/14 – Contract is fully executed and the Curriculum Management System’s implementation begins.
	 
The District’s implementation will integrate well with state efforts since the California Community College Chancellor’s office uses the same software. Fully implemented, this product will help with student learning outcomes (SLOs) and curriculum design, as well as provide support for scheduling and facilitation of catalog production.
	 
Please note this contract includes purchase of Curricunet plus one-year of maintenance fees, total
	 
	 
ing $160,000. On-going maintenance fees are $36,000 per year.
items.item_recommendation: A recommendation that the board of Trustees award a contract to GoverNet for $160,000 for the purchase of Curricunet, an integrated curriculum management system.

items.item_details:
In 2012 the District engaged CampusWorks to provide IT Leadership with one of the deliverables being the replacement of the Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) system.  CampusWorks with the assistance of District Leadership and Ellucian (ERP Vendor) has put together an approach document with a preliminary project plan outlining estimated costs and timelines to deliver the product.  CampusWorks is pleased to present this approach document to the board to receive feedback and address any questions before finalizing a proposal to present to the board as an action item at the September 10 board meeting.
	 
In considering how to achieve the greatest ROI from the ERP replacement, a team of District staff, local companies, higher education vendors with California experience, Ellucian and CampusWorks have joined efforts to provide services, training and support that will convert the current version of the ERP to a contemporary version built on modern infrastructure.  This approach reduces the funding required to move the District and its colleges to a reliable, student service-oriented, and efficient ERP system.  To further extend the value and optimize the investment of the District's bond dollars, the District's Chief Information Systems Officer has assembled a team of qualified, California-experienced vendors to partner with the District to make this conversion happen.  Each vendor's role in the project and the resulting investment will be detailed in a presentation to the board on September 10.  The costs associated with each component are estimated and continued to be refined; however, these costs are significantly less than the option to replace a system that is in wide use.  Early estimates show and investment of $5M to convert to the new ERP solution rather than the $10M originally estimated for a total system replacement.  Any dollars that can be saved on this project are sorely needed to enhance the District's IT infrastructure initiatives that are budgeted in the same bond initiative line item titled ITSS/RIE/ERP.
	 
Of critical note is that the vendor partnerships approach to bring this solution to the District will dramatically reduce costs of the conversion compared to the district using a single vendor.  By combining the expertise of Ellucian, ASR Analytics, local vendors and CampusWorks, total project costs will be contained and hourly rates will be managed at or below industry standards in the San Jose area.
